page.title: 08The Combine Harvester
page.content: Most of the farms around Great Dunmow are arable and therefore need a great deal of machinery. The combine harvester is used for harvesting the crop. This it does by first separating the head of corn from the straw. The head or ear of corn is fed by the trunk head into the drum. The drum then rotates very quickly to thrash the seed out of the chaff. Next the seed falls onto a seive and as the seed goes through the seive a jet of air blows the chaff out the back of the combine and pure seed goes into the tank. With a price of about Â£40,000 and more, combines have to be versatile. With slight alterations the average combine can cut oil seed rape, barley, wheat, peas and beans.
